First, their nature is difficult to guide and they are unrestrained and do not abide; second, the mind of the Way is difficult to guide and their fundamental nature is very profound; third, they enter all fundamental junctures and practice without basis or end; fourth, they enter the minds of the multitude and understand that there are no dharmas.
This is called the inexhaustible treasury of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.

This is called the inexhaustible treasury of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's precepts of not slandering the Dharma, which the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always practice and cultivate.
The Buddha further told ÅšÄriputra:

First, illuminating the Dharma realm and penetrating coming and going.
Second, illuminating the Dharma nature and understanding non-existence.
Third, discerning the flesh eye, the heavenly eye, the wisdom eye, the Dharma eye, and the Buddha eye.
What is the flesh eye?
Observing forms and images is not without eye-consciousness.
What is the heavenly eye?
As for the heavenly eye, it sees heavenly forms and images but does not see retribution and response;

The wisdom eye discriminates and does not see dust and defilements, the Dharma eye is pure and complete with the six perfections, and the Buddha eye clearly sees the characteristics of non-characteristics.

This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's inexhaustible treasury accomplishing the Dharma realm.

First, diligently practicing without fixed intention, some seeking wisdom and some not seeking wisdom, some with an end and some without an end, some with intention and some without intention, internally and externally discriminating as all non-existent.
Therefore, ÅšÄriputra!

The bodhisattva who practices skillful means is foremost in diligently teaching and transforming in all places, and the basis of his practice of precepts is diligent effort. What the TathÄgata speaks is not through written language. Writing is pure, and speaking the Dharma is also pure. This is accumulating the merit of wisdom, establishing patience, and establishing irreversibility.

Even if the trichiliocosm were perfumed with incense and fine silk banners and canopies were offered, he would not be pleased. He is far removed from laziness and does not harbor weakness. They abandon their own comfort and establish a mind of great vows, taking on the suffering of those sentient beings on their behalf. At that time, those who had come to the assembly, upon hearing this profound Dharma, all gave rise to the stage of non-retrogression to the unsurpassed [enlightenment].

The land is fertile and the five grains are cheap, replete with the seven treasures of gold, silver, precious stones, carnelian, agate, pearls, and tiger-patterned amber.
There is a wheel-turning sage king named Rain Flower, followed by the seven treasures.

The so-called seven treasures are: first, the wheel treasure. The wheel treasure is fourteen cubits in diameter, made entirely of the seven treasures, with a thousand spokes, each spoke having a pattern. If the king wishes to go east, the wheel will lead the way.

Second, the elephant treasure. The elephant treasure is the color of white snow, with six tusks, each tusk having a pattern. If the king wishes to ride the elephant to tour the world, in the time it takes to snap one's fingers, he can travel the world without any difficulty.

Third, the horse treasure. The horse treasure has a purple-blue body with a red mane and tail, flies through the air without touching the ground, and when it neighs once it shakes the world so that no one does not hear it. If the king wishes to ride it to the east, west, north, or south, in the time it takes to snap one's fingers he can go everywhere.

Fourth, the jade maiden treasure. The jade maiden treasure has a body that emits the fragrance of blue lotus flowers, and her mouth emits the fragrance of ox-head sandalwood. She is pure flesh without bones, upright, neither fat nor thin, neither tall nor short, neither white nor black, and possesses the sixty-four transformations of a woman. If the king wishes to take her in, she will immediately be in front of him.

Fifth, the pearl treasure. The pearl treasure is three ren square and seven ren high. The pearl moves on its own, following what the king thinks.

Sixth, the precious minister of the treasury. When the wheel-turning sage king wishes to travel to various lands and worlds, passing through the great ocean to the bottomless source, the king wishes to test the precious minister of the treasury, and immediately orders the charioteer:

He then orders the precious minister of the treasury:

The precious minister of the treasury then kneels in the water, takes a vessel to scoop up water, and the seven treasures appear as he wishes.
Seventh, the precious minister of the army. The precious minister of the army, when the king wishes to assemble the four divisions of troops, immediately tells the precious minister of the army:

The precious minister of the army then replies to the king, saying:

The king said:

Then the treasure of the general, following the king's orders, immediately assembled the four types of troops as instructed.
The so-called four types of troops are elephant troops, cavalry, chariot troops, and infantry. Each type of troop has ten divisions, and the four types of troops each have the same number.
At that time, the Buddha told the most victorious ones and all those assembled:

Do not form such a view.
The reason is that the body of the most victorious bodhisattva now is that very one.

Wherever there are transformations, the voice is gentle and soft. Those sentient beings, devas, and humans in that realm distinguish the holy wisdom and the roots of the path without outflows, either demonstrating sounds and pointing to the bright Dharma, using the teaching of hardship to lead them into the Dharma and Vinaya, or using the teaching of the light of spiritual powers and transformations. The Buddha told Shariputra:

All sentient beings have no self or person, all dharmas are originally pure, all dharmas are formless, unattached, and cut off. All dharmas are indestructible, and contemplating the Buddha lands, they are all nonexistent.
Moreover, Shariputra!

The twelve links of dependent origination, the five skandhas, and the six sense faculties are all formless. The Tathagata's eight kinds of sounds are neither male nor female sounds, neither strong nor soft sounds, neither unclear nor turbid sounds, neither masculine nor feminine sounds. The unconditioned path is not seen as a nest. It is praised by the Buddhas of the past, present, and future. What the present Buddha teaches is also without a path.
